_header: When I advertise in my remembrance / And see how fell
Bibliographic Ghosts:
Oxford, Bodleian Library Eng. theol. e.15 (from Hamer (1995)
XHamer, Richard. A Manuscript Index to the Index of Middle English Verse. London: British Library, 1995); see Oxford, Bodleian Library Eng. poet. e.15 (SC 32401); STC4853
_description: Benedict Burgh, ‘Parvus Cato’ — 1185 lines in rhyme royal stanzas and one 8-line Envoy

BodEngPoete15.First Lines:
Whan I aduerte in my remembraunceand se hou feel folke erren
                    greuously…
BodEngPoete15.Last Lines:
…Whan ye it rede lete not your hert be thensDoth as he saith
                    with al your hool entent

BodRawD328.First Lines:
When y adverte yn my remembransAnd see how folke erryt
                    grevusly…
BodRawD328.Last Lines:
…When ye hyt rede lette not yowre hert be þensdoyth as he
                    sayyth with al ys hole entente
BodRawD328.Note: With the usual Latin texts preceding first six stanzas

CULEe431.First Lines:
whenne I advertice in my remembraunceAnd see how fele folke erryn
                    greuously
CULEe431.Last Lines:
who so haue done the goode haue in remembraunceLove euery wyght and
                    that schall the avaunce
CULEe431.Note:
With Latin above the first two stanzas and to the right of the third
                    through the sixth, beginning above the first: ‘Cvm animauerterem quam
                    plurimos homines grauiter errare…’

CULFf49.First Lines:
Whan I adu[er]tese to my remenbrauunceAnd see how fele folke erryn
                    grevously
CULFf49.Last Lines:
Whan ye it rede lete not your hert be thencedothe as þis saythe
                    w[i]t[h] all yo[ur] hole ententExplicit
CULFf49.Note:
Latin prose texts precede each stanza, beginning ‘Cum anima
                    adu[er]tere[m]…’ on f. 87v.

CULHh412.First Lines:
Whan I aduertyse in my remembranceAnd see how feele folk erre
                    greuously…
CULHh412.Last Lines:
Whan ȝe it rede lat not ȝowr hert be thensdoth as thys
                    saith w[i]t[h] all ȝowr hoole entent
CULHh412.Note:
Latin preceding each first 6 stanzas, the first beginning ‘Cvm
                    a[n]i[m]aduertere[m] q[ui]a plurimos ho[m]i[n]es in via mor[um] graueter errare
                    opinioni eorum fore me…’
